title: Will legislation raising the US federal minimum wage become law before 20 August 2021?
preds: Just a gut feeling from observations and listening to news
One week away and isn't Congress now on summer break?
Updated to 0% based on topics and issues on which POTUS and Congress are focused.
The senate and the house currently have no sessions. The house returns 08/31.

I'm just anchoring again with the crowd.  You know it's Okay to change your mind, as the information change. A Bayesian statistic method. Yet, to stick to your guts the first time, or have very few prediction change and still be right. That's super forecasting, or maybe I'm wrong.  I'm only human, I no nothing.
not enough of a push to happen that quickly
Revising down to 1%.  Don't see this anywhere on the horizon.
No. Since the Senate parliamentarian ruled this could not be included in a reconciliation bill, a minimum wage would never get past a filibuster.
No. This is too short of a timeframe. 30 December would tempt me to raise my odds just a bit.
With the passage of time, and no legislation pending, seems less and less likely.

My 8 ball says, "Very Doubtful." I'm CHANGING MY MIND, last time I gave a 15% probability, this time I'm lowering it to 1% probability. Maybe, it's an anchoring effect? We will see, 20 August 2021 is just around the corner. Legislation decisions, people are unpredictable. Based on this question, we will see if this Wisdom of the Crowd knows how our leaders are thinking?
Highly unlikely based on public opinion and republicans refusing to give Biden a win even if it helps their constituents.  Possible for 2022, depending on political winds

Senate rejects Sanders $15 minimum wage hike ... The overwhelming vote raises doubts whether Biden will be able to raise the federal minimum wage to $15 at any point in his first term.
=> Then definitely not gonna happen within the next 45 days if it's not obvious at all if this could happen in Biden's first term. 
... minimum wage has not been increased since 2009 in the US. So probably some compromise will happen to an amount between 10 to 12 and then, as Manchin suggested, indexing it to inflation.  https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/541826-senate-rejects-sanders-15-minimum-wage-hike

Given what already happened (strong opposition : https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/541826-senate-rejects-sanders-15-minimum-wage-hike), it looks very unlikely that there be a law before 20 August 21 on it.

With just a few days left before recess, I don't see a way this can happen within the question's window.
Changed it from 5% to 1%, looks unlikely given the disagreement in this matter.
Just not going to happen any time soon.

They are struggling with things they mostly agree about in the Senate, and they don’t agree on this. Attempts to tie it to too much other stuff probably makes passage less likely. Maybe they will start on something simple in the fall. Something closer to Manchin’s step plus indexing.

Seems like an uphill battle for sure with 8 Democrats having voted against it.  But, it is still a Biden priority, AND, Manchin wanted it to be $11/hour, not the $15 proposed.  And the Dem objections were largely "procedural"?  Maybe there is a tiny possibility given that the question does not specify it has to be $15, or any effective date required.  We just have to watch if any other legislation gets proposed in the near future.  If it does not, I will slide back to 2, then 1, then 0.

My 8 ball says, "Yes".  I give the legislation 15% probability of changing their minds, with an important need to raise the minimum wage before 20 August 2021. The pandemic has shown the inequality of society. I believe society demands it's government(s) to make fair and end the inequality that plague today.

People I speak to believe as I do that businesses will make the case that it should be left to the states.  Republicans and some Dems think this is not good for their constituents, i.e. their large business donors.
Very unlikely. Breaking the filibuster would be necessary. But possible, a small increase would resolve "yes" and it's not impossible for that to be included in a larger compromise bill.
First, Biden has too many other issues he has to deal with.  Second, this is a nonstarter with Republicans, so it won't happen.  Breaking the filibuster for this is not going to happen.
-2 Biden has too many other priorities and with the filibuster in place it's essentially a non-starterr.

The President also issued an Executive Order on April 27, 2021 requiring Federal contractors pay their employees—hundreds of thousands of workers who are
working on Federal contracts—a minimum wage of at least $15 per hour. To make it into law for all employees it will need to pass with the 22 Budget before 1 October, unlikely to be achieved in this timeline.

No chance. It would require too much political capital for the Biden Administration to strongarm and would require conditional votes from Manchin, Collins, and a few other people who are not viewing the democratic party with good graces.
It doesn't have the unbridled support it needs

Very, very little chance. The economy is already showing many signs of (inflation, gas prices, underwhelming job numbers) causing problems for the administration. 15 dollar minimum wage would be a political fight that 1.) wouldn't help, and 2.) the smarter Democrats know this. Furthermore, 2 votes keep the Dems from full party unity on the filibuster and they show no signs of budging because if they do they'll lose their Senate seats in the next election. The biggest economic/domestic legislation the Biden admin/Dem-controlled Congress will pass has most likely already been passed.

Given the small time window until 20 August and the little progress that has been made, I don't see this as possible.
I do think it's above 0%, but its hard to justify betting on a 1 in 50 or so chance in a challenge with 15 questions, even if the payoff would be large.
Monkeys will re-write The Decameron before any wage increase gets passed! Did that one smelled?
This is just not going to happen, at least before August 20th.

Going to zero in tandem with my view on a separate question on filibuster reform with which this question is linked.  As long as Joe Manchin and Kirsten Synema oppose filibuster reform, this legislation will likely encounter Republican filibusters before August 20, 2021 and beyond. I believe there is a strong public sentiment toward raising the minimum wage (>60% would approve an increase). However, there has not been an increase in decades, indicating low desire from the government to pass such legislation. Legislation introduced both in other bills and independently has not passed, despite public desire for its passage. Due to increasing pressure for legislative change to ameliorate the harms of the pandemic, I believe there is a higher chance than in 2019 of the legislation passing, but still a very low chance.

The change to federal contractors is likely both a conciliatory attempt as well as aiming to nudge the long term prospects of raising it. It's likely if it happens at all it will be a much longer game to achieve.

Upping minimum wage for federal contractors probably indicates lack of appetite on the part of Biden to push for a global legislation, otherwise the federal change would be irrelevant. Already highly unlikely as explained before.
Can't pass with reconciliation. Too many other priorities on the table right now to be complete within 3 months.

I think it will go to 11-12$ but not to 15.

There is much better chance of a modest increase, but no chance of the doubling. This outcome will be associated with the debate on filibuster (or more exactly new exceptions to supermajority requirements).

The only hope of raising the minimum wage is via budget reconciliation. Despite broad public support, thanks to Citizens United, business interests can buy too many members of Congress to pass if 60 Senate votes would be required. As for taking advantage of the recent ruling by the Senate Parliamentarian https://www.npr.org/2021/04/05/984596350/ruling-by-senate-parliamentarian-opens-up-potential-pathway-for-democrats which would enable a simple majority vote in the Senate, this assumes a blue wall of 100% of all Senate Democrats against upping the minimum wage. Could every one of them resist corporate money, especially as this can be done through "dark money" so voters would never know who pulled their Senators' strings?
As much as I believe raising the minimum wage is long past due, the U.S. Senate does not seem inclined to go along.

With Manchin saying he will accept no alteration of the filibuster, I don’t see how any legislation can pass the Senate by August.1] The Dems are already abiding by the Parliamentarian’s ruling that a minimum wage provision cannot be included in a reconciliation bill. Any lone Republican can hold consideration long after August in this scenario.  Minority Leader McConnell is replaying his early Obama model of denying all support to the new President to make him a one-termer, so I see little way to horse trade for this priority. McConnell surely knows this will greatly aid the Dems in the mid term campaign.  As others have noted, infrastructure will take up the political oxygen for the majority of the summer, so I doubt a bill will even reach a Senate vote during the time frame of the question.  I do not see a scenario where 10 Republicans vote for cloture on a minimum wage provision before August. [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/joe-manchin-filibuster-vote/2021/04/07/cdbd53c6-97da-11eb-a6d0-13d207aadb78_story.html
Too many factors, and in-power party opposition, against it.

Too many "wants" including minimum wage are being bundled into core driving legislative initiatives like infrastructure and opposition to increasing federal debt and overlap with state roles are increasing.

A national wage raise is long overdue, as there has been significant inflation since the $7.25 wage was instituted. I assign a small 10% probability to a compromise increase happening later this year with republican support, but I believe the probability is small since the minimum wage violates the Byrd rule for reconciliation. I only see this happening if it was decided that minimum wage policy does not violate the Byrd rule, or if there are major republican concessions, both of which I deem relatively unlikely. The reason why I assign 10% instead of lower is because I believe that the midterm elections wouldn't be kind to the Democrats, based on historical trends. They likely know this, and that increases the likelihood of compromise, though they might use the compromise to boost their electoral chances closer to midterms, which would push it past Aug 2021.

It´s very unlikely that this would happen, because the minimum wage didn´t increase since 2009 and it is a very high change. Also there is The Raise the Wage Act, which shows that the minimum wage should be by 15$ in 2025.

So, add on some weeks for that. There are procedural hurdles regarding how many reconciliations there can be in any  fiscal (calendar?) year, so that pushes second part of any "infrastructure" into next fiscal year. Manchin has signaled an openess for $12. Senate parliamentarian has previously ruled against a wage hike being part of reconciliation process.  A lot is stacked against a wage hike by august.

Though US economy is having a rebound in paper, but it's too early for rising the minimum wage, companies are still facing low sales and productivity. Furthermore with lot of govt supports toward population already there's no urgent needs to give rise which can be detrimental to short term economic growth because it shift the burden toward corporate instead of govt. If it goes to reconciliation then it depends on how many Dems are against the bill.

I give this a very low probability. The senate vote shows this measure isn't even supported by all democrats, let alone the 10 republicans needed to get this trough the senate. its also unlikely that the democrats will (or even can) remove the filibuster (1). Another thing to consider, will Biden (and the democratic party) spend political capital on this issue when they're already busy with his infrastructure bill? 1:
https://www.businessinsider.com/democratic-sen-manchin-opposed-to-removing-filibuster-2021-3?international=true&r=US&IR=T

Picking apart the question a little, the words "become law" could be important. It implies concurrence by both bodies, which could disqualify efforts through executive order or regulatory change. Given the short four month time frame for resolution, it's unlikely that a stand alone bill would make it through the process. That leaves the only viable path to yes as a rider on another bill. While that tactic is possible, the democrats need to decide how to spend there political capital. I sincerely think there will be a push for an increase to the minimum wage, but doubt that it occurs this quickly.
The republican objection to raising the minimum wage will continue to grow, blocking attempts outside direct legislation which the democrats appear unwilling to pursue.

On the one hand, Senate Parliamentarian's ruling today opens new opportunities for Dems through reconciliation beyond even the upcoming Infra Bill [1]. On the other, the Parliamentarian has already ruled that minimum wage hikes fall outside bounds for a Reconciliation bill [2].  Does this mean that ALL minimum wage hikes would be out of bounds for the newly minted "third and fourth" reconciliation shots awarded to this congress (over these next 2 years) or was it just the wording contained in the COVID Relief bill that could be amended to get it past the Parliamentarian (any legislative experts / senate procedure geeks out there want to weigh in on that one??!!)? Then there's the other bills taking a front row seat (notably voting rights which, after Infra, is likely to take up a lot of bandwidth). And the fact that, right now, Joe Biden and Co are riding high on record popularity with what they've already done (and therefore don't really need to push hard for another wage increase as a priority for right now). Lastly, we need to ask when is the most politically opportune moment to do this? -When popularity starts lagging as COVID passes and the slow recovery starts wearing at people's tolerance (and their wallets)?
-Closer to the election to gain credit that is actually reflected in the voting booths (and mitigating the average American voter's goldfish standard memory capacity for political considerations)?
-When Republicans (and troublesome Dems) will be harmed most by public obstinance and obstruction to it (see above)? With all the above in play, and with everything else going on, I think it seems more likely that, even if they could get it done by Q3 this year, Dems will hold onto this one until closer to election time to win hearts and minds in the build up to what could be a consequential mid term. [2] https://edition.cnn.com/2021/02/25/politics/minimum-wage-covid-relief-senate-parliamentarian/index.html

Sen. Manchin previously objected to a nationwide $15/hr minimum wage.  Since he now stands athwart the infrastructure package, a high priority for the Biden administration, bargaining will ensue. Both the minimum wage and the corporate tax rate are likely to be involved. The president might be willing to trade the minimum wage for a reasonably intact infrastructure bill, on the assumption that a reopening economy and a hot labor market might do the work for him in the short run. If the Democrats hold both chambers in '22, the issue could be revisited.

If last summer's activism continues into this summer, then there could be a successful push to end the filibuster.  When the filibuster ends, then this bill has a higher percent chance of passing.  Additionally, there are rumors that President Biden may forgive student loans via executive order. An executive order forgiving student loans, may lead to a minimum wage executive order, depending on the outcry after the student loan forgiveness.

I am not as down on this as the crowd, but I am pretty down on it. Mitt Romney and Tom Cotton co-sponsored their own minimum wage increase, so there is definitely some common ground on the need to raise the federal minimum wage. However, this bill would still reach the following obstacles:
- Lack of progressive support. Most Blue states, and progressive districts, already have minimum wages above that proposed by Republicans. Additionally, Chuck Schumer is the Majority Leader and he has been working very hard to keep progressives on-board so I doubt he is going to look for a middling minimum wage compromise. For perspective, the Romney-Cotton bill was not well received by the left and any add ons to a minimum wage will further kill momentum.
- A difficult bi-partisan environment. Mitch McConnell is sticking to the same strategy and the pressure seems to be on most GOP members to oppose everything Biden wants to do.  Where this gets possible is the scenario if the filibuster gets repealed. In which case, I would say this is pretty likely. Notably, most filibuster reform focuses on narrow carve-outs for voting rights laws so there is a very low probability scenario where filibuster reform makes this feasible. But it's worth considering.

The base rate for bills passing US Congress is 1-3%. This bill is highly controversial and (by my subjective opinion) doesn't seem to be a core message of the Biden Admin, so I adjust the base rate down by ~50%.
highly unlikely given partisan divide on the issue and congressional calendar

I think there will be significant opposition to Biden's agenda.  I think this will be the least of this worries.  Maybe there could be a small increase.  I'll have to keep this forecast updated during the summer.

I can see something happening as part of a broader movement to address economic disparities across the socioeconomic spectrum, particularly but not solely because of the pandemic's hit to lower-wage service workers. Perhaps they'll split the difference between $7.25 and $15 or something.

“If the progressive view is that it’s $15 or nothing, they may end up with nothing,” said Glenn Spencer, head of the Chamber’s Employment Policy Division. It seems there is bi-partisan support for the $10-12 range but that will almost certainly won't get support from more progressive democrats. It's a catch-22 that's unlikely to be sorted out before Aug 20. It's bound to be an easier argument in a full-employment environment and that's still a while away. While not impossible, it seems improbable in the given timeframe.

Based on the insights gleaned from other posters (as I know nothing about the different factors involved here), it seems unlikely. Given that it won't be part of the reconciliation bill, it will require 60 votes to pass, and given the makeup of the Senate, even if the 8 procedural objections flip I think a solid baseline probability is close to 0%.
I think given Biden's strong stance on this, during his term it's probable that there will be some kind of minimum wage increase, but in the next 4-5 months? That's not much time for negotiating (and I'm sure there will have to be some, to reach 60 votes).

This question is ambiguous.  I would say the chance of getting the minimum wage to $15 is 0.  But the question does not ask that; it asks whether the federal minimum wage will be raised without specifying the level.  I would say the chance of Congress raising the minimum wage by some amount is still close to 0 given (1) the greater focus on voting rights and the infrastructure bill and (2) likely resistance from many Democrats to raising it to less than $15.
The GOP is pushing back and this won’t happen in this economy cycle ...

I am strong on this for a few reasons 
It was a central feature on his election platform https://joebiden.com/empowerworkers/
He has stuck to his agenda since being elected
The economy is on the rebound
The people that it effects are not typical savers so it will give the economy a kick.   
It will be staggered and some people will miss out eg wait staff. The question only asks about legislation and not the amount, timing or who it applies to.

So I think the main barrier to this happening is that the minimum wage hike was struck from the COVID relief package by the Senate parliamentarian for violating the Byrd Rule. The Democratic majority in the Senate means they can only pass reconciliation bills, and the minimum wage isn't allowed to be in that type of bill, so it would need to be passed with the 60 vote majority that all other bills face.  The last minimum wage increase was in 2007 only 14 years ago and it passed the Senate 94-3 once tax credits for small businesses were added. The vast majority of Americans agree in every poll I've found in researching this that $7.25 is too low, the main stumbling block in both parties is whether $15 is too high for every geography. That said, Romney and Cotton introduced a bill raising it to $10 (and mandating E-Verify), and Manchin supports $11 tied to inflation going forward. There's definitely some appetite for it on both sides. There's a lot going against it though. Polarization is probably the most obvious. The Senate sucks at passing bills, especially bills on contentious topics, and it failed to pass one on this already. Even if compromise would be possible, Democrats wouldn't want to annoy the increasingly large left wing demanding $15 by going lower, and Republicans wouldn't want to give a win on that big of a talking point to the "far-left", or want $15 simply by their constituents' policy preferences. There's not really a stand-alone proposal that can satisfy enough people here. The main possibility would be through compromise on ancillary issues (hence Romney/Cotton's E-Verify inclusion).  Another big issue is that this isn't a predominantly federal problem, so a lot of activist pressure isn't going toward the federal government. The federal minimum wage is the wage floor of wage floors, since states can pass their own minimum wages. 29 + DC have already done that, not to mention city-specific minimum wages that are already $15 in NY and SF. Having higher wages in cities is less contentious, a lot of the debate around raising the federal level comes around mandating it in states with lower costs of living, and those states tend to be Republican. Many people are enthusiastic about a $15 minimum wage, but in practice they don't seem to direct their energies to a place (i.e. the federal government) where it would lead to national legislation. On the Republican side, $7.25 being too low isn't super controversial, but there aren't particularly vocal demands to fix it either.  The last difficulty is the idea that getting things done in Washington requires political capital, and this is currently a fairly low priority issue that would be big from a talking point perspective, and thus (I'm guessing) be costly from a political capital lens. The main goals of the Biden administration have been pretty explicit, and they've been about COVID, infrastructure, and climate, and all of those are massive issues to tackle. Per accounts of the Obama administration, lack of capital was the primary barrier to getting climate policy since he spent it all on healthcare. The concept is obviously a bit abstract, but its cited enough in political reporting and memoirs that I'm inclined to go with it. Climate is a huge issue, as is infrastructure, and together they're probably going to be a sole focus of the administration, leaving little for minimum wage issues. The yes case for this would probably be that a federal minimum wage raise to something that isn't $7.25 per hour could be quietly added to a different bill. State-level efforts can continue to raise the minimum wage in areas with high cost of living to satisfy the left, and Republicans can get compromise points for getting something done on a relatively uncontroversial issue while not giving into the $15 demands. Again, the minimum wage being higher than $7.25 isn't all that controversial, even among Republicans. The main issue here would be that any reasonable increase in the federal minimum wage would only substantively affect red states, so there may be little appetite for it among Democrats who'd prefer the $15 their constituents want. Considering the recent minimum wage bill didn't try to reach a compromise on amount and instead put forth $15 to predictably fail, it doesn't seem like there's much appetite for it right now.  The last consideration to take note of is the time frame. We'll still be exiting COVID by the time the deadline comes around, and unemployment will probably still be elevated, which a minimum wage hike would exacerbate. The budget resolution passed in February explicitly said no raising of the minimum wage during "a global pandemic" as one of the reserve funds parameters. Even if it would be for the future, discussion through August will probably skew toward job creation, which favors an infrastructure bill, rather than wages.  Overall, not impossible, but not much reason for it to happen. Raising it to above $7.25 isn't very controversial, but the recent history looks bad, the time frame is limiting, there's no great stand-alone idea, and the momentum at the federal level isn't there from activists or the administration. Weirder things have happened in politics, but I don't see much reason to bank on this one.

Two-thirds of Americans reportedly support raising the min. wage to $15. Most action on the issue has been in states and (some) municipalities so far. (Current federal $7.25 min. wage remains in use in 21 states.) https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2021/03/12/when-it-comes-to-raising-the-minimum-wage-most-of-the-action-is-in-cities-and-states-not-congress/ There's possibly room for compromise in Congress but likely on a lower increase. Whether that actually happens by 8/20/21 seems uncertain right now...much on the agenda.  (https://www.wsj.com/articles/democrats-minimum-wage-setback-could-kick-start-talks-with-republicans-11615057218)
It won't be raised to $15/hr, but I think there's a good chance of it being increased from the current unreasonably low rate.
There is an agenda, first things first, and the first thing is climate infrastructure. Physics says time exists so everything doesn't happen at once.

A number of states stick with the rate determined by FLSA.  However, Georgia and Wyoming maintain a $5.25 minimum wage.  American Samoa is complex, but rates generally are maintained at a quite low rate.  I do believe a minimum wage will be determined.  However, I don't think $15 will be the number.  The only states above $10 appear to be more affluent.  Certainly the fact that Georgia's governor is Republican along with Wyoming's will have an impact upon the discussion.
It's important for Biden to get this done, so I see humans the Democrats pushing hard for it

The minimum wage bill does not immediately raise it to $15, but gradually increases it over the next four years.  Many states have already passed state laws.  Increasing wages lowers need for financial assistance from the government. It has bipartisan support, the key question isn’t support, it is votes, which is why I am not all in. Also, the timeline means that it needs to have priority.   https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/26/politics/congress-15-dollar-minimum-wage-increase-democrats/index.html

Regarding the other question about changing the filibuster, I don't see that happening this year. Secondly, not happening through budget reconciliation as we know. Thirdly, don't believe enough Republicans will vote to raise the minimum wage by August 20th.

It wouldn't be to $15/hour, but it might be to $9.50, $10 or $11 an hour. I think this is somewhat likely by the end of the year and very likely before midterm elections, but by Aug. 20? Probably not. The current first priority seems to be a bill on China, and then an infrastructure bill; a minimum wage bill probably won't be pursued until after these. And an infrastructure bill is going to take some time. Every legislator has to get his or her individual concerns and needs addressed. And this infrastructure bill will be huge. It's not clear to me that the infrastructure bill will be passed by Aug. 20, and I can't see getting that *and* a bill on China *and* a minimum wage bill through by Aug. 20.
https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/23/politics/joe-biden-legislative-priority-list/index.html
https://www.forbes.com/sites/jonathanponciano/2021/03/14/democrats-big-and-green-multi-trillion-dollar-infrastructure-plan/ Addendum: Just looking through everyone's forecasts this evening. And well, aren't we all over the map!

I lean toward less likely because the timeframe is sort of short and it is likely going to be hard to pass. The parliamentarian has said they can't do it through reconciliation and the moderate Democrats want to follow the appropriate procedures. So unless they negotiate a smaller increase with Republican support I'm not sure how they can do it. That makes me think it probably won't happen in the next six months if it can happen at all. I'm still giving it a 1 in 4 chance though because a minimum wage increase is pretty popular with Republican voters so an increase to $10 or something could be a desirable compromise for everyone.

I do not see how the minimum wage increase fits into limits set by budget reconcilation process. So i assume this would require a sepaeate action.  Meaning fillibusters and agreements by 60 senators.  This is link to think tank heritage which is conservative (too say the least) https://www.heritage.org/budget-and-spending/commentary/harmful-minimum-wage-increase-not-eligible-reconciliation.
Personally, if you can only get 11 or $12 why not settle for that as legislation. But in this environment of all or nothing an d any compromise is a monstrosity, it is not going to happen. I am not even going to hedge by going 10%. Just straight 0. Not that i would be sad if i was wrong but i don't see a coming together moment for the senate.

Unlikely. Sen. Sinema already voted against the minimum wage as part of the relief bill (http://kold.com/2021/03/05/sinema-facing-backlash-after-voting-no-raise-wages-act/) and not just on procedural grounds - in 2016 she refused to sign onto a $15 minimum wage bill: https://jonathancohn.medium.com/why-do-these-64-democrats-not-support-a-15-minimum-wage-d96a5527f41b) Sen. Manchin has also repeatedly blocked efforts to raise the minimum wage (including the 2016 bill above): https://www.businessinsider.com/manchin-poses-threat-to-progressives-plan-to-raise-the-minimum-wage

Pretty good chance, if the Ds can get it in budget rec;  this will be tricky but is possible.   My fellow Republicans, at least those outside the Northeast, remain terrified of everything new.   Easy way to keep the parties straight:  Democrats help people; Republicans judge people.
